p.s: If a child repeatedly acts aggressively , you might wonder “ What am I doing wrong ? ”
Instead of getting down on yourself about a child 's tendency to shout , hit , or push , use the problem as a benchmark for teaching the child more appropriate ways to behave .
Be sure not to respond to their aggression with your own .
Keep your cool and show the child how to problem-solve common situations and express themselves using assertiveness .

list.item:
Stay calm .
Resist the urge to behave aggressively yourself .
Take a few deep breaths or silently count to 10 to maintain your composure .
When you are in control of your own emotional reaction , the child can look to your example for managing tough situations .

item.s: Remove the child from the environment .
Break aggressive behaviors by making the child leave the situation .
For example , if they are playing rough with siblings , make them take a timeout .
If they act up in the grocery store , leave .
If you 're shopping with a companion , have that person escort them outside .
If the child purposefully uses aggression to get out of undesirable activities or situations , use another approach .
Do n't allow them to leave .
Do n’t spank the child .
Because you 're trying to instill the idea that aggression is n't the solution , avoid spanking an aggressive child .
Instead , use consequences that help them actually learn from their mistakes and inspire better behavior in the future .
For instance , you might have the aggressive child repeat writing a sentence , like “ I will not push in line .
I will keep my hands to myself and wait until my turn . ”
Set clear limits and adhere to clear consequences .
Be sure the child knows what 's expected of them by explaining the rules .
Post them in a common area , such as on the refrigerator or in the common room .
When the child breaks a rule , calmly state what they did wrong and the consequence for their acting out .
Say something like , “ We do n't kick one another , Bryan .
Because you kicked your brother , you wo n't be allowed to finish watching the show .
Go to your room and read a book . ”
Be consistent with discipline .
Across situations and caregivers , it 's important to maintain consistency .
Do n't overlook aggressive behaviors at home , but discipline the child when they occur in public .
Similarly , if one parent sets a rule or consequences for aggression , the other parent needs to get on board also .
If you do n't consistently stop and address aggressive behavior , the child wo n't be motivated ( or reminded ) to change it .
Take a timeout to regulate your own emotions if the child hurts you .
If you get caught in the middle of the child 's aggression , take a moment to take care of yourself .
Tell the child " Ow , you hurt me ! I will talk to you once I 've calmed down .
" Then , go into another room , nurse your wounds , and calm down before enforcing any consequences .
It 's easy to respond unfavorably if the aggressive child has caused you physical pain .
To prevent a reaction that starts a cycle of violence , pause and take care of yourself first .

list.item:
Brainstorm replacement behaviors .
Once you tell the child that their behavior is unacceptable , encourage them to use their words to think of solutions .
You might say , “ Can you think of a better way to ask for the toy ? ”

item.s: Role-play how the child should react .
Go over effective ways of reacting to common situations together .
Act as the other person and let the child practice using their words to express themselves or ask for something .
For example , you might practice letting the child ask nicely to use something rather than pushing another child or snatching away a toy .
Reward appropriate behaviors .
Increase the child 's likelihood of behaving appropriately by praising or rewarding those behaviors when you see them .
Say , “ I like how you used your words ! ” or give them a treat for practicing self-control .
Rewarding positive behavior is a much more effective method than punishing the child for negative behavior .
Channel aggressive energy in positive ways .
Help the child release energy in adaptive ways like exercising or playing .
Let the child run in the park , do jumping jacks , or play Frisbee with the dog to release aggressive energy .
Some children need more frequent and consistent outdoor time than others , and this could be the case for this child . \
Having these outlets might reduce their aggressive , acting-out behaviors .
Appeal to the child 's self-interest .
Help them see that acting out gets them into trouble and doing replacement behaviors helps them avoid consequences .
Show them what 's in it for them when they behave appropriately .
You might say , “ You get into trouble when you push or hit .
When you use your words , you are more likely to get what you want . ”
Whether you 're dealing with a teen or a younger child , you wo n't necessarily curb aggressive behaviors by trying to make the child empathetic to the victim .
Continue to make it very clear that aggressive behaviors wo n't be tolerated .

list.item:
Look for patterns in their aggression .
Most kids act out in the same ways over and over again .
Spotting these recurring patterns can help you get to the core problem .
For instance , maybe the adolescent is more likely to push and hit when they are feeling scared .
Perhaps the toddler kicks when they are tired .
Noticing the context of aggressive behavior can help you come up with practical solutions , such as addressing the child 's fear or ensuring they are well-rested .

item.s: Get feedback from others .
Coordinate with other caregivers and teachers to determine if they witness aggressive behavior .
Talking to others can also clue you in on the cause of the behaviors .
For instance , maybe the child has been acting out at school .
If the behaviors are n't happening at home or in other environments , you may need to work with the school to address the root cause , which could be bullying or even a learning delay .
See a therapist .
If you feel stumped about handling the aggressive child , consider seeing a professional .
They can work with the child to figure out the unmet underlying need that leads to aggression .
They can also teach you more positive parenting practices to curb aggressive behavior in the child .
